              Collapse Subdiscussion Simon Jones

              Simon Jones

              Sep 22, 2018 Sep 22, 2018 at 12:14
              Also in regards to activity 3: Noah creating the blog itself isn't an ethics issue, nor is his failure to "point out" the value of having 17,000 followers. Whether he misled them through omission, or just genuinely enjoyed being active on Twitter and didn't consider the impact, he rightfully requested PhoneDog for permission to keep his Twitter blog, which they agreed to, including the benefits of Kravitz continuing to Tweet on their behalf (presumedly with their permission, direction or guidance on content, whether sales or marketing). There's a number of false assumptions in it as well. The Twitter blog attracted 17,000 followers. There is no guarantee that everyone following a Twitter handle would actually be a PhoneDog customer (they might have been advertised on friends or other recommendations), or whether it was a customer list at all. They also didn't invest a substantial amount of money growing this list, as the creation and growth was provided by Kravitz. Presumedly the only real cost would be his salary, and seeing as how he didn't do it at the companies direction, it's a reasonable assumption to state that he was initially employed for other reasons, so the net cost to growing this list would be zero. Is it ethical to consider the Twitter account to be the property of PhoneDog, including its followers, when it was created through work (whether at their direction or not)? Absolutely. However, they chose to relinquish those rights (which in itself is a right that a copyright or IP owner possesses). Deciding later or going back on your deal (or contract based ethics) and based on a number of false premises, and in doing so they are unethical. I would argue that Kravitz was in the right, for both ethical and legal reasons. I also hope that PhoneDog has since declared bankruptcy, or been acquired by a competent parent company. I don't believe these issues are unique to cybertechnology either, as it would be similar to having a written list or notebook of customer or contact details.
              Manage Discussion Entry
              • Go To Topic

              Also in regards to activity 3:

              Noah creating the blog itself isn't an ethics issue, nor is his failure to "point out" the value of having 17,000 followers. Whether he misled them through omission, or just genuinely enjoyed being active on Twitter and didn't consider the impact, he rightfully requested PhoneDog for permission to keep his Twitter blog, which they agreed to, including the benefits of Kravitz continuing to Tweet on their behalf (presumedly with their permission, direction or guidance on content, whether sales or marketing).

              There's a number of false assumptions in it as well. The Twitter blog attracted 17,000 followers. There is no guarantee that everyone following a Twitter handle would actually be a PhoneDog customer (they might have been advertised on friends or other recommendations), or whether it was a customer list at all. They also didn't invest a substantial amount of money growing this list, as the creation and growth was provided by Kravitz. Presumedly the only real cost would be his salary, and seeing as how he didn't do it at the companies direction, it's a reasonable assumption to state that he was initially employed for other reasons, so the net cost to growing this list would be zero.

              Is it ethical to consider the Twitter account to be the property of PhoneDog, including its followers, when it was created through work (whether at their direction or not)? Absolutely. However, they chose to relinquish those rights (which in itself is a right that a copyright or IP owner possesses). Deciding later or going back on your deal (or contract based ethics) and based on a number of false premises, and in doing so they are unethical.

              I would argue that Kravitz was in the right, for both ethical and legal reasons. I also hope that PhoneDog has since declared bankruptcy, or been acquired by a competent parent company. I don't believe these issues are unique to cybertechnology either, as it would be similar to having a written list or notebook of customer or contact details.

                Collapse Subdiscussion Edward Davis

                Edward Davis

                Sep 23, 2018 Sep 23, 2018 at 10:34
                Regarding euthanasia, this could be seen as a base assertion fallacy as the argument assumes to be dogmatically true due to religious beliefs.Without the influence of their faith would their opinions differ? Is there room for religious beliefs in ethical discussions?
                Manage Discussion Entry
                • Go To Topic

                Regarding euthanasia, this could be seen as a base assertion fallacy as the argument assumes to be dogmatically true due to religious beliefs.
                Without the influence of their faith would their opinions differ? Is there room for religious beliefs in ethical discussions?

                  Collapse Subdiscussion Shyam Nath

                  Shyam Nath

                  Sep 23, 2018 Sep 23, 2018 at 21:37
                  🖖 Hello World,   Activity 1   I find it most difficult to pretend that euthanasia is "ethically right in order to relieve pain and suffering"; existence/time is more valuable, since you cannot lose, but if you don't live as long as you can, then you lose experience/time (for a cure), and why do you live? To be, or not to be, that is the query… (Potentially insensitive religious joke: If religious people believe they will goto heaven, why don't they go now? Maybe it's not as good as they say it is? You only need one person to spread the message, and they only need to spread it to one person before leaving; like pass the parcel…)   I also find it most difficult to accept the Oxford dictionary definition for the term; Life Stinks taught me "nobody dies peacefully in their sleep" ∵ "it's what they tell people to make them feel good" (they also demonstrate what ℝælly happens; not for the faint of heart) ∴ death is always a painful experience.   And I doubt great apes would consent to euthanasia: P(1): Euthanising animals does not involve informed consent. C(0)∴ Euthanising animals is unethical…unless it's a self-cannibalising octopus? No; cure the causal stress/boredom instead.   1. My assumed position does not necessarily believe all acts of euthanasia are "ethically right in order to relieve pain and suffering" ∴ if it's involuntary/abused/exploitative/ETC, then it's unethical.   2. My assumed position does not necessarily involve religion (even if does, it doesn't specify which religion); I'll use my religion as an exempli gratia (since I'm unfamiliar about other religions, and I don't want to offend anyone who follows them): in the Bhagavad-Gītā (a pre-war conversation between Kṛṣṇa, and Arjuna; they both have relatives, and friends, on both sides of the war, and Arjuna doesn't want to kill his relatives, and friends), Kṛṣṇa peer-pressures Arjuna into performing his duty as a warrior (with the use of karma, and stuff; it's like 700 verses, or something...).   3. My assumed position does not necessarily believe all acts of euthanasia are "ethically right in order to relieve pain and suffering" ∴ if the patient is suffering from depression/mania/hysteria/psychosis/invalidity/insanity/pāgala/mūḍha/ETC, they should be referred to a psychiatrist/psychologist/ETC for treatment. Also, "right to die" should only mean suicide; if you can't do it yourself (Stephen Hawking can blink; a particular blinking gesture could trigger self-destruction), then you probably don't ℝælly want to die.   Activity 2   If someone is proved to have betrayed their country, it is fine to torture them in order to learn about who they work for. It is not only generally acceptable to do so, but such practice is even legal. Domain: Ethics ∵ it involves the well-being of sentient entities.   Lying is a terrible habit. It damages the reputation of the person. It is very difficult to trust a dishonest person. Further, most religions also strongly condemn and prohibit lying. Domain: Ethics ∵ lying is unethical.   Interracial marriage is not a good idea. Many societies have socially stigmatized interracial marriages. Domain: Ethics ∵ discrimination is unethical.   It is correct to wear a helmet when riding a bicycle because this is the law in our state. Domain: Ethics ∵ it involves the well-being of sentient entities.   Activity 3   Anybody who responds to this is in my group, but since it's probably going to be too late; Me, Myself, and I…   This would've been so much better if PhoneDog Media was UpDog instead.   "Initially, PhoneDog seemed to have no problem with this arrangement."; the word "seemed" is indicative of equivocation ∴ Noah should've made an announcement @Phonedog_Noah that he was leaving, and would be @NoahKravitz; but some people only hear what they want to hear, and willn't pursue written contractual confirmation in fear of a mishearing (In 1964, Warren Buffett, and Seabury Stanton (Berkshire Hathaway CEO), had a verbal contract to sell his Berkshire Hathaway shares at $11.50 per share, but the written contract was surreptitiously undercut to $11.37; he ended up not selling, instead buying more shares, until he owned enough shares to fire Seabury Stanton for his insolence).   An ethical issue, not unique to cybertechnology, was an ex-employee posting on behalf of their former company; this is like authors/composers/scientists/ETC selling to people who claim authorship/composition/discovery/ETC.   Another ethical issue, not unique to cybertechnology, was Noah wanting to keep the company Twitter blog instead of starting again from scratch; it's like wanting to keep/continue/ETC scientific research, after leaving Edison Laboratory.   LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,AGENT S.🕴Migrating Infestive Bugs !!

                  🖖 Hello World,
                   
                  Activity 1
                   
                  I find it most difficult to pretend that euthanasia is "ethically right in order to relieve pain and suffering"; existence/time is more valuable, since you cannot lose, but if you don't live as long as you can, then you lose experience/time (for a cure), and why do you live? To be, or not to be, that is the query… (Potentially insensitive religious joke: If religious people believe they will goto heaven, why don't they go now? Maybe it's not as good as they say it is? You only need one person to spread the message, and they only need to spread it to one person before leaving; like pass the parcel…)
                   
                  I also find it most difficult to accept the Oxford dictionary definition for the term; Life Stinks taught me "nobody dies peacefully in their sleep" ∵ "it's what they tell people to make them feel good" (they also demonstrate what ℝælly happens; not for the faint of heart) ∴ death is always a painful experience.
                   
                  And I doubt great apes would consent (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site. to euthanasia:
                  P(1): Euthanising animals does not involve informed consent.
                  C(0)∴ Euthanising animals is unethical…unless it's a self-cannibalising (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site. octopus? No; cure the causal stress/boredom instead.
                   
                  1. My assumed position does not necessarily believe all acts of euthanasia are "ethically right in order to relieve pain and suffering" ∴ if it's involuntary/abused/exploitative/ETC, then it's unethical.
                   
                  2. My assumed position does not necessarily involve religion (even if does, it doesn't specify which religion); I'll use my religion as an exempli gratia (since I'm unfamiliar about other religions, and I don't want to offend anyone who follows them): in the Bhagavad-Gītā (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site. (a pre-war conversation between Kṛṣṇa, and Arjuna; they both have relatives, and friends, on both sides of the war, and Arjuna doesn't want to kill his relatives, and friends), Kṛṣṇa peer-pressures Arjuna into performing his duty as a warrior (with the use of karma, and stuff; it's like 700 verses, or something...).
                   
                  3. My assumed position does not necessarily believe all acts of euthanasia are "ethically right in order to relieve pain and suffering" ∴ if the patient is suffering from depression/mania/hysteria/psychosis/invalidity/insanity/pāgala/mūḍha/ETC, they should be referred to a psychiatrist/psychologist/ETC for treatment. Also, "right to die" should only mean suicide; if you can't do it yourself (Stephen Hawking can blink; a particular blinking gesture could trigger self-destruction), then you probably don't ℝælly want to die.
                   
                  Activity 2
                   
                  If someone is proved to have betrayed their country, it is fine to torture them in order to learn about who they work for. It is not only generally acceptable to do so, but such practice is even legal.
                  Domain: Ethics ∵ it involves the well-being of sentient entities (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site..
                   
                  Lying is a terrible habit. It damages the reputation of the person. It is very difficult to trust a dishonest person. Further, most religions also strongly condemn and prohibit lying.
                  Domain: Ethics ∵ lying is unethical (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site..
                   
                  Interracial marriage is not a good idea. Many societies have socially stigmatized interracial marriages.
                  Domain: Ethics ∵ discrimination is unethical (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site..
                   
                  It is correct to wear a helmet when riding a bicycle because this is the law in our state.
                  Domain: Ethics ∵ it involves the well-being of sentient entities (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site..
                   
                  Activity 3
                   
                  Anybody who responds to this is in my group, but since it's probably going to be too late; Me, Myself, and I…
                   
                  This would've been so much better if PhoneDog Media was UpDog instead.
                   
                  "Initially, PhoneDog seemed to have no problem with this arrangement."; the word "seemed" is indicative of equivocation ∴ Noah should've made an announcement @Phonedog_Noah that he was leaving, and would be @NoahKravitz; but some people only hear what they want to hear, and willn't pursue written contractual confirmation in fear of a mishearing (In 1964, Warren Buffett, and Seabury Stanton (Berkshire Hathaway CEO), had a verbal contract to sell his Berkshire Hathaway shares at $11.50 per share, but the written contract was surreptitiously undercut to $11.37; he ended up not selling, instead buying more shares, until he owned enough shares to fire Seabury Stanton for his insolence).
                   
                  An ethical issue, not unique to cybertechnology, was an ex-employee posting on behalf of their former company; this is like authors/composers/scientists/ETC selling to people (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site. who claim authorship/composition/discovery/ETC.
                   
                  Another ethical issue, not unique to cybertechnology, was Noah wanting to keep the company Twitter blog instead of starting again from scratch; it's like wanting to keep/continue/ETC scientific research, after leaving Edison Laboratory (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site..

                    Shyam Nath

                    Sep 25, 2018 Sep 25, 2018 at 20:02
                    PS: I have more Hindu counterexamples for activity 1.2.   Counterexample 2   In the kalisantaraṇopaniṣad; brahmā tells nārada that chanting the mahā-mantra 35,000,000 times "will cross the sin of the murder of a Brahmin. One becomes purified from the sin of the theft of gold. One becomes purified from the sin of association with a woman of low caste. One can be purified from the sins of wrong done to Pitrs, Devas and other people in material world. Having given up all Dharmas, one can becomes freed at once from all sins altogether and at once released from all bondage." (source).   It's possible to chant the mahā-mantra 35,000,000 times in a little over half a decade (5.222789 years); at a rate of 170 rounds/rosaries per day (rounds are 108) ∵ 35,000,000 = 108 × 170 × 365 × 5.22279 ∴ in a hundred year life; you could kill about 20 brāhmaṇa, and you'll still be safe from yamarāja/yamadūta/ETC.   Counterexample 3   If a sannyāsa becomes fallen (compromised/corrupt/ETC), they must kill themselves (¿in the gaṅgā?); this is what guru jokingly say, before informing that in kali-yuga this is not the case, but I haven't discovered any vedic evidence to support this claim, nor do I believe in it enough to search (when I take sannyāsa, I willn't become fallen ∵ becoming fallen is like marrying God, and then cheating on God; it's unethical).   Counterexample 4   As mahā-viṣṇu creates universes from every outward breath, he also destroys universes from every inward breath; killing uncountables.   Counterexample 5   kalki'll use a flaming sword (like in Game of Thrones) to kill all the rakṣasā/cāṇḍāla/śūdra/mleccha/ETC, all whilst riding a white horse (I assume he'll be chopping off their heads from that height).   Assumed Knowledge 47   trimūrti:    ‣ brahmā is the creator; like The Architect in The Matrix.    ‣ nārada is the son of brahmā; like the Prime Program in The Matrix.    ‣ nārada is a personal friend of kṛṣṇa, like arjuna.    ‣ nārada "possesses a music box that allows him to travel through space/time on the sound generated by his music box (hmm, well this is how I remember it; it was something to do with plucking the strings... string theory); also describes a TARDIS-like structure (higher dimensionality)" (source: "A temporal theory of The Doctor, or two, or more..."…it's just some"-thing" I wrote a few years ago; the music box is a tanpura, and there's higher dimensions in the vedas)   hare kṛṣṇa mahā-mantra:    hare kṛṣṇa hare kṛṣṇa    kṛṣṇa kṛṣṇa hare hare    hare rāma hare rāma    rāma rāma hare hare   varṇa-āśrama:    ‣ brāhmaṇa are like jedi (¿saints?)    ‣ sannyāsa are brāhmaṇa who can become guru    ‣ guru are like yodas (¿popes?)    ‣ "To accept sannyāsa means to commit civil suicide, but sannyāsa is compulsory, at least for every brāhmaṇa, every first-class human being." -- source    ‣ "Lord Caitanya said, 'For a sannyāsī, or anyone who is aspiring to get out of the clutches of material nature and trying to elevate himself to the spiritual nature and go back to home, back to Godhead, for him, looking towards material possessions and women for sense gratification—not even enjoying them, but just looking toward them with such a propensity—is so condemned that he had better commit suicide before experiencing such illicit desires.'" -- source   yuga:    ‣ kali-yuga is the most sinful time of existence, and we are in it right now; wubba lubba dub-dub!!! :D   daśāvatāra:    ‣ kalki is a future reincarnation of kṛṣṇa.    ‣ "Thereafter, at the conjunction of two yugas, the Lord of the creation will take His birth as the Kalki incarnation and become the son of Viṣṇu Yaśā. At this time almost all the rulers of the earth will have degenerated into plunderers." -- source    ‣ "May Kalkideva, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, who appeared as an incarnation to protect religious principles, protect me from the dirt of the Age of Kali." -- source    ‣ "Lord Kalki, the annihilator of the meat-eaters posing as kings." -- source    ‣ "Lord Kalki will appear in the home of the most eminent brāhmaṇa of Śambhala village, the great soul Viṣṇuyaśā." -- source    ‣ "When the Supreme Lord has appeared on earth as Kalki, the maintainer of religion, Satya-yuga will begin, and human society will bring forth progeny in the mode of goodness." -- source
                    Manage Discussion Entry
                    • Go To Parent
                    PS: I have more Hindu counterexamples for activity 1.2.
                     
                    Counterexample 2
                     
                    In the kalisantaraṇopaniṣad (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.; brahmā tells nārada that chanting the mahā-mantra 35,000,000 times "will cross the sin of the murder of a Brahmin. One becomes purified from the sin of the theft of gold. One becomes purified from the sin of association with a woman of low caste. One can be purified from the sins of wrong done to Pitrs, Devas and other people in material world. Having given up all Dharmas, one can becomes freed at once from all sins altogether and at once released from all bondage." (source (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.).
                     
                    It's possible to chant the mahā-mantra 35,000,000 times in a little over half a decade (5.222789 years); at a rate of 170 rounds/rosaries per day (rounds are 108) ∵ 35,000,000 = 108 × 170 × 365 × 5.22279 ∴ in a hundred year life; you could kill about 20 brāhmaṇa, and you'll still be safe from yamarāja (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site./yamadūta (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site./ETC.
                     
                    Counterexample 3
                     
                    If a sannyāsa becomes fallen (compromised/corrupt/ETC), they must kill themselves (¿in the gaṅgā?); this is what guru jokingly say, before informing that in kali-yuga this is not the case, but I haven't discovered any vedic evidence to support this claim, nor do I believe in it enough to search (when I take sannyāsa, I willn't become fallen ∵ becoming fallen is like marrying God, and then cheating on God; it's unethical).
                     
                    Counterexample 4
                     
                    As mahā-viṣṇu (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site. creates universes from every outward breath, he also destroys universes from every inward breath; killing uncountables.
                     
                    Counterexample 5
                     
                    kalki'll use a flaming sword (like in Game of Thrones) to kill all the rakṣasā (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site./cāṇḍāla (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site./śūdra (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site./mleccha (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site./ETC, all whilst riding a white horse (I assume he'll be chopping off their heads from that height).
                     
                    Assumed Knowledge 47

                        Scott Feeney

                        Scott Feeney

                        Sep 29, 2018 Sep 29, 2018 at 21:53
                        Hi Monica, Try the following: In the left column, select Collaborate Ultra. Click the 'hamburger' icon up towards the top left of the screen. Select Recordings. This will bring up the list of the recordings.  Select the recording you wish to view. Hope this helps! Scott    
                        Manage Discussion Entry
                        • Go To Parent

                        Hi Monica,

                        Try the following:

                        1. In the left column, select Collaborate Ultra.
                        2. Click the 'hamburger' icon up towards the top left of the screen.
                        3. Select Recordings.
                        4. This will bring up the list of the recordings. 
                        5. Select the recording you wish to view.

                        Hope this helps!

                        Scott

                      • Shyam Nath
                        Shyam Nath
                        Sep 23, 2018 Sep 23, 2018 at 21:37
                        🖖 Hello World,
                         
                        Activity 1
                         
                        I find it most difficult to pretend that euthanasia is "ethically right in order to relieve pain and suffering"; existence/time is more valuable, since you cannot lose, but if you don't live as long as you can, then you lose experience/time (for a cure), and why do you live? To be, or not to be, that is the query… (Potentially insensitive religious joke: If religious people believe they will goto heaven, why don't they go now? Maybe it's not as good as they say it is? You only need one person to spread the message, and they only need to spread it to one person before leaving; like pass the parcel…)
                         
                        I also find it most difficult to accept the Oxford dictionary definition for the term; Life Stinks taught me "nobody dies peacefully in their sleep" ∵ "it's what they tell people to make them feel good" (they also demonstrate what ℝælly happens; not for the faint of heart) ∴ death is always a painful experience.
                         
                        And I doubt great apes would consent (Links to an external site.) to euthanasia:
                        P(1): Euthanising animals does not involve informed consent.
                        C(0)∴ Euthanising animals is unethical…unless it's a self-cannibalising (Links to an external site.) octopus? No; cure the causal stress/boredom instead.
                         
                        1. My assumed position does not necessarily believe all acts of euthanasia are "ethically right in order to relieve pain and suffering" ∴ if it's involuntary/abused/exploitative/ETC, then it's unethical.
                         
                        2. My assumed position does not necessarily involve religion (even if does, it doesn't specify which religion); I'll use my religion as an exempli gratia (since I'm unfamiliar about other religions, and I don't want to offend anyone who follows them): in the Bhagavad-Gītā (Links to an external site.) (a pre-war conversation between Kṛṣṇa, and Arjuna; they both have relatives, and friends, on both sides of the war, and Arjuna doesn't want to kill his relatives, and friends), Kṛṣṇa peer-pressures Arjuna into performing his duty as a warrior (with the use of karma, and stuff; it's like 700 verses, or something...).
                         
                        3. My assumed position does not necessarily believe all acts of euthanasia are "ethically right in order to relieve pain and suffering" ∴ if the patient is suffering from depression/mania/hysteria/psychosis/invalidity/insanity/pāgala/mūḍha/ETC, they should be referred to a psychiatrist/psychologist/ETC for treatment. Also, "right to die" should only mean suicide; if you can't do it yourself (Stephen Hawking can blink; a particular blinking gesture could trigger self-destruction), then you probably don't ℝælly want to die.
                         
                        Activity 2
                         
                        If someone is proved to have betrayed their country, it is fine to torture them in order to learn about who they work for. It is not only generally acceptable to do so, but such practice is even legal.
                        Domain: Ethics ∵ it involves the well-being of sentient entities (Links to an external site.).
                         
                        Lying is a terrible habit. It damages the reputation of the person. It is very difficult to trust a dishonest person. Further, most religions also strongly condemn and prohibit lying.
                        Domain: Ethics ∵ lying is unethical (Links to an external site.).
                         
                        Interracial marriage is not a good idea. Many societies have socially stigmatized interracial marriages.
                        Domain: Ethics ∵ discrimination is unethical (Links to an external site.).
                         
                        It is correct to wear a helmet when riding a bicycle because this is the law in our state.
                        Domain: Ethics ∵ it involves the well-being of sentient entities (Links to an external site.).
                         
                        Activity 3
                         
                        Anybody who responds to this is in my group, but since it's probably going to be too late; Me, Myself, and I…
                         
                        This would've been so much better if PhoneDog Media was UpDog instead.
                         
                        "Initially, PhoneDog seemed to have no problem with this arrangement."; the word "seemed" is indicative of equivocation ∴ Noah should've made an announcement @Phonedog_Noah that he was leaving, and would be @NoahKravitz; but some people only hear what they want to hear, and willn't pursue written contractual confirmation in fear of a mishearing (In 1964, Warren Buffett, and Seabury Stanton (Berkshire Hathaway CEO), had a verbal contract to sell his Berkshire Hathaway shares at $11.50 per share, but the written contract was surreptitiously undercut to $11.37; he ended up not selling, instead buying more shares, until he owned enough shares to fire Seabury Stanton for his insolence).
                         
                        An ethical issue, not unique to cybertechnology, was an ex-employee posting on behalf of their former company; this is like authors/composers/scientists/ETC selling to people (Links to an external site.) who claim authorship/composition/discovery/ETC.
                         
                        Another ethical issue, not unique to cybertechnology, was Noah wanting to keep the company Twitter blog instead of starting again from scratch; it's like wanting to keep/continue/ETC scientific research, after leaving Edison Laboratory (Links to an external site.).
                         

                        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,

Matt Parker (Links to an external site.) discovered geometric patterns in supermarkets (to challenge archæological claims), which leads me to doubt there'd be much difference between a criminal mind, and an ethical crackers' mind; is there a neuroplastic difference between people who pretend to be criminals, and people who pretend to be the opposite gender?
                         
                        Medical professionals are incompetent; they prescribe drugs that have adverse side effects, risking the lives of their patients on a potentially lethal "cure".
                         
                        James Randi routinely makes a habit of attempting to overdose on homeopathic medicine live on stage, in an attempt to disprove it; but IMO, all he's proving is that it could be a contributing factor to his longevity/health/ETC, and the fact that overdosing isn't lethal means it's a safe form of medication that seems to have no side effects (Links to an external site.) (which means it's functional (Links to an external site.)!!! :D).

                        🖖 Hello Shaahin, Monica, Bernard, and Simon,
                         
                        The results of the experiment are linked to the bystander effect; not only their predilection for an authority figure, but also their velleity.
                         
                        It'd probably be more traumatising just to witness, let alone make the decision that led to, the untimely death of a relative/friend; although, some find it trivial to be insensitive to deaths which occurred further away in time (Horrible Histories), even if they're unknowingly related (Links to an external site.).
                         
                        It doesn't matter how many people die, a reminder of the dangers's unavoidable; it's fallacious to think that more people need to die to make a difference ∵ even though crimes are punished (sometimes severely/lethally) many times, many criminals still exist who commit those same crimes.

                      • Shyam Nath
                        Shyam Nath
                        Sep 24, 2018 Sep 24, 2018 at 11:12
                        🖖 Hello Scott, Simon, Glen, Monica, and Craig,
                         
                        Some music shops allow customers to listen to music (¿legally/ethically?), before purchasing a copy.
                        Some food shops allow customers to taste the food, before purchasing a copy.
                        Book shops allow customers to read, before purchasing a copy.
                        Furniture shops allow customers to sit/lie/ETC on chairs/beds/ETC, before purchasing a copy.
                        Customers should be allowed to watch the movie, before purchasing a copy.
                        The reason why this isn't the case, is due to movies usually only being watched once per customer, and the inability to ensure customers can only use it once in their lifetime.
                         
                        If you purchase a physical copy, and overtime it becomes damaged; you have to purchase another physical copy, just like any other physical item.
                         
                        It is not "our moral duty is to pay to enjoy and appreciate and applaud their creative works"; we only enjoy/appreciate/applaud good quality creative works that we actually enjoy/appreciate/applaud. It is not unethical to criticise ∵ it is unethical (Links to an external site.) to lie; although, if you have no"-thing" nice to say, don't say any"-thing" at all (unless it's constructive (Links to an external site.)).
                         
                        P(1): Video games are like (choose you own adventure) story/game books.
                        C(0)∴ Customers should be allowed to play video games, before purchasing a copy.
                         

                        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
                        AGENT S.
                        🕴
                        Migrating Infestive Bugs !!

                        View in discussion
                      • Shyam Nath
                        Shyam Nath
                        Sep 25, 2018 Sep 25, 2018 at 10:56
                        🖖 Hello Timothy, Simon, and Rhys,
                         
                        P(2): Lazyness makes us unhealthy.
                        P(1): Piping water makes us lazy.
                        C(0)∴ We should labouriously bucket water from wells/streams/rivers/ETC instead.
                         

                        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,

                        Sep 25, 2018 Sep 25, 2018 at 11:13
                        🖖 Hello Danny, and Joshua,
                         
                        It's more beneficial to the open source project that the military makes professional/paid contributions.
                         
                        It goes against hacking culture to be oppressive (Links to an external site.) in the freedom (Links to an external site.) of how users use software; "Using things in a unique way outside their intended purpose is often perceived as having hack value." #Hacking_Ethics (Links to an external site.)
                         

                        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,

                        Sep 25, 2018 Sep 25, 2018 at 11:33
                        PS: The military has already made significant contributions that led to the technology we use today; the test (Links to an external site.), the bug (Links to an external site.), the computer (Links to an external site.), the internet (Links to an external site.), ETC…
                        View in discussion
                      • Shyam Nath
                        Shyam Nath
                        Sep 25, 2018 Sep 25, 2018 at 20:02
                        PS: I have more Hindu counterexamples for activity 1.2.
                         
                        Counterexample 2
                         
                        In the kalisantaraṇopaniṣad (Links to an external site.); brahmā tells nārada that chanting the mahā-mantra 35,000,000 times "will cross the sin of the murder of a Brahmin. One becomes purified from the sin of the theft of gold. One becomes purified from the sin of association with a woman of low caste. One can be purified from the sins of wrong done to Pitrs, Devas and other people in material world. Having given up all Dharmas, one can becomes freed at once from all sins altogether and at once released from all bondage." (source (Links to an external site.)).
                         
                        It's possible to chant the mahā-mantra 35,000,000 times in a little over half a decade (5.222789 years); at a rate of 170 rounds/rosaries per day (rounds are 108) ∵ 35,000,000 = 108 × 170 × 365 × 5.22279 ∴ in a hundred year life; you could kill about 20 brāhmaṇa, and you'll still be safe from yamarāja (Links to an external site.)/yamadūta (Links to an external site.)/ETC.
                         
                        Counterexample 3
                         
                        If a sannyāsa becomes fallen (compromised/corrupt/ETC), they must kill themselves (¿in the gaṅgā?); this is what guru jokingly say, before informing that in kali-yuga this is not the case, but I haven't discovered any vedic evidence to support this claim, nor do I believe in it enough to search (when I take sannyāsa, I willn't become fallen ∵ becoming fallen is like marrying God, and then cheating on God; it's unethical).
                         
                        Counterexample 4
                         
                        As mahā-viṣṇu (Links to an external site.) creates universes from every outward breath, he also destroys universes from every inward breath; killing uncountables.
                         
                        Counterexample 5
                         
                        kalki'll use a flaming sword (like in Game of Thrones) to kill all the rakṣasā (Links to an external site.)/cāṇḍāla (Links to an external site.)/śūdra (Links to an external site.)/mleccha (Links to an external site.)/ETC, all whilst riding a white horse (I assume he'll be chopping off their heads from that height).
                         
                        Assumed Knowledge 47
                         
                        trimūrti (Links to an external site.):
                           ‣ brahmā (Links to an external site.) is the creator; like The Architect (Links to an external site.) in The Matrix.
                           ‣ nārada (Links to an external site.) is the son of brahmā; like the Prime Program (Links to an external site.) in The Matrix.
                           ‣ nārada is a personal friend of kṛṣṇa, like arjuna.
                           ‣ nārada "possesses a music box that allows him to travel through space/time on the sound generated by his music box (hmm, well this is how I remember it; it was something to do with plucking the strings... string theory); also describes a TARDIS-like structure (higher dimensionality)" (source: "A temporal theory of The Doctor, or two, or more..."…it's just some"-thing" I wrote a few years ago; the music box is a tanpura (Links to an external site.), and there's higher dimensions (Links to an external site.) in the vedas)
                         
                        hare kṛṣṇa mahā-mantra (Links to an external site.):
                           hare kṛṣṇa hare kṛṣṇa
                           kṛṣṇa kṛṣṇa hare hare
                           hare rāma hare rāma
                           rāma rāma hare hare
                         
                        varṇa (Links to an external site.)-āśrama (Links to an external site.):
                           ‣ brāhmaṇa (Links to an external site.) are like jedi (¿saints?)
                           ‣ sannyāsa (Links to an external site.) are brāhmaṇa who can become guru
                           ‣ guru (Links to an external site.) are like yodas (¿popes?)
                           ‣ "To accept sannyāsa means to commit civil suicide, but sannyāsa is compulsory, at least for every brāhmaṇa, every first-class human being." -- source (Links to an external site.)
                           ‣ "Lord Caitanya said, 'For a sannyāsī, or anyone who is aspiring to get out of the clutches of material nature and trying to elevate himself to the spiritual nature and go back to home, back to Godhead, for him, looking towards material possessions and women for sense gratification—not even enjoying them, but just looking toward them with such a propensity—is so condemned that he had better commit suicide before experiencing such illicit desires.'" -- source (Links to an external site.)
                         
                        yuga (Links to an external site.):
                           ‣ kali-yuga (Links to an external site.) is the most sinful time of existence, and we are in it right now; wubba lubba dub-dub!!! :D
                         
                        daśāvatāra (Links to an external site.):
                           ‣ kalki (Links to an external site.) is a future reincarnation of kṛṣṇa (Links to an external site.).

                           ‣ "Thereafter, at the conjunction of two yugas, the Lord of the creation will take His birth as the Kalki incarnation and become the son of Viṣṇu Yaśā. At this time almost all the rulers of the earth will have degenerated into plunderers." -- source (Links to an external site.)

                           ‣ "May Kalkideva, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, who appeared as an incarnation to protect religious principles, protect me from the dirt of the Age of Kali." -- source (Links to an external site.)
                           ‣ "Lord Kalki, the annihilator of the meat-eaters posing as kings." -- source (Links to an external site.)
                           ‣ "Lord Kalki will appear in the home of the most eminent brāhmaṇa of Śambhala village, the great soul Viṣṇuyaśā." -- source (Links to an external site.)
                           ‣ "When the Supreme Lord has appeared on earth as Kalki, the maintainer of religion, Satya-yuga will begin, and human society will bring forth progeny in the mode of goodness." -- source (Links to an external site.)
                        Edited by Shyam Nath on Sep 25, 2018 at 20:37

                        PSSSSS: Humanity originated from south africa ∴ all humans are african ∴ racial supremacists are self-loathing…well, I still think redheads came from mars (recessive from earthly genetic incompatibilities, and failed martian experiments in The Pursuit of Happyness/immortality/perfection/ETC), and the stonehenge was their stargate (which resulted in the destruction of their failing planet); but this hairbrained theory (including; dark/brown/black hair is from earthly cabbage patch dark/brown/black soil, and yellow/white hair are albino mutants ∵ quod erat demonstrandum ∎) conflicts against my martian theory (which only explains where all the water went, and isn't backed by science, but is backed by the vedas; wubba lubba dub-dub!!! :D).

                      • Shyam Nath
                        Shyam Nath
                        Sep 26, 2018 Sep 26, 2018 at 15:42
                        PSSSSSS: OMG; I just ℝised why vulcans're (Links to an external site.) green-blooded!!! :D
                         
                        P(3): You're what you eat.
                        P(2): Vulcans're vegan/herbivores.
                        P(1): Plants're green.
                        C(0)∴ Vulcans're plants!
                         
                        And I thought 'twas ∵ vulcans're green, and aliens're green c̄ a green middle term.
                        (I also ℝised it can be contracted for any word!!! :D)

                      • Shyam Nath
                        Shyam Nath
                        Sep 26, 2018 Sep 26, 2018 at 22:04
                        🖖 Hello Samuel,
                         
                        What does euthanasia, from the 1ˢᵗ activity, have to do c̄ cyberethics?
                        What does any of the arguments, from the 2ⁿᵈ activity, have to do c̄ cyberethics?
                        And none of the 3ʳᵈ activity are unique to cyberethics.
                        What does your post have to do c̄ cyberethics?
                        Instead of hypocriticising; why don't you lead by example?
                         
                        On the subject of cyberetiquette:
                        P(2): You haven't referenced any cyberetiquette standards for this online community.
                        P(1): Many online communities have differing cyberetiquette standards.
                        C(0)∴ This online community has no cyberetiquette standards.

                        PS: Customers can watch movie trailers, before purchasing a copy; and game demos are sometimes released too.

                        View in discussion
                      • Shyam Nath
                        Shyam Nath
                        Sep 27, 2018 Sep 27, 2018 at 8:28
                        🖖 Hello Christopher,
                         
                        The concept of uneducated/ignorance is so unethical that some human subject researchers've gone so far as to perform experiments on themselves ∵ in the face of the unknown, the lack of knowledge can be too unpredictably hazardous to allow other humans to risk their own lives for the sake of an experiment that may only serve the interests of a minority, and mayn't even be fruitfully beneficial; since experiments are only performed to resolve uncertainties, and we're doing just fine pre-experiment.
                         
                        Human Experimentation: The Good, The Bad, & The Ugly (Links to an external site.)
                         
                        6 Stupid and Dangerous Things Scientists Did to Themselves (Links to an external site.)
                         

                        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
                        AGENT S.
                        🕴
                        Migrating Infestive Bugs !!

                        There's also the possibility they'll just fake it (Links to an external site.).
                        Even if they manage to get it right, who is responsible & punishable for the childs' actions; the parent, or the child?

                         ‣ Universal Paperclips (Links to an external site.); instrumental convergence (Links to an external site.), value drift (Links to an external site.), ETC (Links to an external site.).
                         ‣ The Ur-Quan Masters (Links to an external site.); paperclip probes (Links to an external site.), flying spaghetti monsters (Links to an external site.), and an upcoming sequel (Links to an external site.).
                         ‣ SPACEPLAN (Links to an external site.); Planet of the Potatos.
                         ‣ Galaxia (Links to an external site.); I can't remember, but I think you play an artificial intelligence hell bent on galactic invasion & domination.
